description: New Latin acadēmīa, from Ancient Greek Ἀκαδημία (Akadēmía), a grove of trees and gymnasium outside of Athens where Plato taught; from the name of the supposed former owner of that estate, the Attica hero Akademos. Doublet of academy and Akademeia; see also academe. Modern sense of “the world of universities and scholarship” recorded from 1956.

entries.meaning: (collective) The scientific and cultural community engaged in higher education and research, taken as a whole. [from 1956]
examples: Academia continues to provide scientific education, despite attempts to turn it into a system of professional schooling.

entries.meaning: Continuous study at higher education institutions; scholarship.
examples: Not every university graduate wishes to pursue academia.
